\section{PrimeFlux: Core Definitions and Operators}
\label{sec:PF-core}

In this section we introduce the basic objects of the PrimeFlux framework:
prime distinctions, the dual congruence rails, a PF Hamiltonian, an
evolution operator, and the combinatorial manifold built from least common
multiples. The emphasis is on formal definitions; physical interpretation
is postponed to later sections.

\subsection{Primes as distinctions and the dual rails}

Let $\mathcal{P}$ denote the set of prime numbers. In PrimeFlux, each
$p \in \mathcal{P}$ is interpreted as an \emph{irreducible distinction},
and composite integers encode structured interactions of these distinctions.

A standard observation is that every prime $p \geq 5$ satisfies
\[
  p \equiv 1 \pmod{6}
  \quad\text{or}\quad
  p \equiv -1 \pmod{6}.
\]
This partitions all but finitely many primes into two congruence classes.
We therefore define the two PF rails
\begin{align*}
  \mathcal{P}_{+} &:= \{\, p \in \mathcal{P} \mid p \equiv 1 \pmod{6} \,\}, \\
  \mathcal{P}_{-} &:= \{\, p \in \mathcal{P} \mid p \equiv -1 \pmod{6} \,\},
\end{align*}
and treat $\{2,3\}$ as a finite exceptional set. The sets
$\mathcal{P}_{+}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{-}$ are referred to as the positive and
negative rails; they form the basic two-sheet structure on which PrimeFlux is built.

\begin{definition}[Prime distinction amplitudes]
Let $s \in \R$ or $\C$ be a scale parameter. A \emph{prime distinction amplitude}
at scale $s$ is a function
\[
  \Psi(\cdot,s) : \mathcal{P} \to \C, \qquad p \mapsto \Psi(p,s),
\]
interpreted as the contribution of the distinction $p$ at scale $s$.
\end{definition}

In many constructions the multiplicative factors $p^{-s}$ provide a canonical
choice of amplitude, possibly with rail-dependent phases. For the algebraic development
we keep $\Psi$ abstract.

\begin{definition}[PrimeFlux Hamiltonian]\label{def:PF-Hamiltonian}
Let $\Phi_{+}$ and $\Phi_{-}$ be linear operators on PF state spaces
$\mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(+)}$ and $\mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(-)}$ representing evolution on
the positive and negative rails, and let $T$ be a linear operator encoding
coupling between the two rails. The \emph{PrimeFlux Hamiltonian} is the block operator
\[
  H_{PF}
  :=
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \Phi_{+} & T \\
    T^{*}    & \Phi_{-}
  \end{pmatrix},
\]
acting on $\mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(+)} \oplus \mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(-)}$. We assume that
$H_{PF}$ is densely defined and symmetric (or self-adjoint) on a suitable domain.
\end{definition}

Informally, $\Phi_{+}$ and $\Phi_{-}$ capture intrinsic dynamics along the rails,
while $T$ and $T^{*}$ measure the interaction between them. The off-diagonal structure
is responsible for interference between prime modes on the two rails.

\subsection{Evolution operator and PF dimension}

Given a Hamiltonian, it is natural to consider its associated flow operator.

\begin{definition}[PF evolution operator]\label{def:PF-evolution}
Let $H_{PF}$ be as in Definition~\ref{def:PF-Hamiltonian}. For $\tau \in \R$ such
that the exponential is defined (e.g. via functional calculus when $H_{PF}$ is
self-adjoint), the \emph{PrimeFlux evolution operator} is
\[
  U_{PF}(\tau) := \exp(- \tau H_{PF}).
\]
\end{definition}

The parameter $\tau$ plays the role of an evolution or flow variable, whereas
$s$ appearing in spectral terms $p^{-s}$ is interpreted as a dimension/scale parameter
of the distinction manifold.

\begin{definition}[PF effective dimension]\label{def:PF-dimension}
Fix a reference base $\pi > 1$. For a prime $p \in \mathcal{P}$ and scale $s$ with
$\Re(s)>0$, the \emph{PF effective dimension} is
\[
  d_{PF}(p,s) := \frac{\ln(p^{\,s})}{\ln \pi} = \frac{s \ln p}{\ln \pi}.
\]
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition}[Basic properties of $d_{PF}$]\label{prop:dPF-basic}
Let $p$ be a fixed prime.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
  \item For real $s_1,s_2$, $d_{PF}(p,s_1+s_2)=d_{PF}(p,s_1)+d_{PF}(p,s_2)$.
  \item For $s>0$, $p \mapsto d_{PF}(p,s)$ is strictly increasing.
  \item For $s \neq 0$,
    \[
      d_{PF}(p,1/s) = \frac{1}{s^2} d_{PF}(p,s^2).
    \]
\end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Parts (a) and (b) follow from logarithm identities and monotonicity. For (c),
\[
  d_{PF}(p,1/s) = \frac{1}{s}\frac{\ln p}{\ln \pi}
  = \frac{1}{s^2} \left(s \frac{\ln p}{\ln \pi}\right)
  = \frac{1}{s^2} d_{PF}(p,s^2).
\]
\end{proof}

\subsection{The PF LCM manifold}\label{subsec:PF-LCM}

\begin{definition}[PF LCM manifold]\label{def:PF-LCM}
Let $\mathcal{P}$ denote the set of prime numbers. The \emph{PF LCM manifold} is the
free abelian group
\[
  \Lambda_{\!PF} := \bigoplus_{p\in\mathcal{P}} \mathbb{Z}\,\omega_p,
\]
whose basis vectors $\omega_p$ correspond to prime distinctions. A weight vector
\[
  w = \sum_{p\in\mathcal{P}} \nu_p\,\omega_p
\]
encodes the $p$-adic exponents of a composite state
\[
  n = \prod_{p\in\mathcal{P}} p^{\nu_p}.
\]
For each $s$ with $\Re(s)>0$, the PF LCM manifold is equipped with a curvature metric
$g_s$ defined on basis vectors by
\[
  g_s(\omega_p,\omega_q) = \delta_{pq}\,p^{-s},
\]
extended bilinearly; we refer to $\{g_s\}_s$ as the PF curvature family. Rail-interaction
terms determined by the PF Hamiltonian $H_{PF}$ enrich these metrics, turning
$\Lambda_{\!PF}$ into a weighted distinction manifold induced by prime attenuation and dual-rail dynamics.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}\label{rmk:LCM-interpretation}
\hfill
\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(1) Weight-lattice interpretation.}
The PF LCM manifold plays the same structural role as the weight lattice in classical
Lie theory: primes correspond to fundamental weights $\omega_p$; PF composites are
integral weight vectors; PF flows act linearly on $\Lambda_{\!PF}$.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(2) Superposition and dimensional uplift.}
The exponents $(\nu_p)$ determine the superposition geometry of a PF state:
\[
  n = \prod p^{\nu_p} \quad\longleftrightarrow\quad w = \sum \nu_p \omega_p,
\]
where $w$ is a point in a countably infinite-dimensional Euclidean space with PF
curvature. The attenuation $p^{-s}$ and its dual $p^{-1/s}$ determine the effective PF
dimension, the embedding inside the PF superposition manifold, and how rail phases
encode physical identity.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(3) Roles of $2$ and $3$.}
Primes $2$ and $3$ anchor the two fundamental rail directions $6k\pm1$. They remain
basis elements in $\Lambda_{\!PF}$, but PF geometry distinguishes their scaffolding
role from the curvature primes $p\equiv\pm1\pmod{6}$.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(4) Particle/antiparticle dual manifolds.}
PF duality $p^{-s} \leftrightarrow p^{-1/s}$ induces paired manifolds
$\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(+)}$ and $\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(-)}$ for resonance vs. anti-resonance
states. A PF particle resides on $\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(+)}$ with attenuation $p^{-s}$, and
its dual state lives on $\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(-)}$ with $p^{-1/s}$, forming a Lie-theoretic
pair analogous to $\lambda$ and $-w_0(\lambda)$ in minuscule representation theory.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(5) Physical interpretation.}
The PF LCM manifold encodes the internal address of a composite system and determines
its curvature contribution, resonance phase, PF dual, and representation type under
$\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$. This is the geometric bridge between number-theoretic distinction
fields and Lie-theoretic representation geometry.
\end{remark}

\section{PrimeFlux as a Lie Algebra}
\label{sec:PF-Lie-algebra}

We now identify a natural Lie algebra structure carried by the PrimeFlux
distinction manifold. This structure provides a direct bridge between the
PrimeFlux formalism and the standard language of Lie theory.

\subsection{PF state space and distinction flows}

Let $\mathcal{P}$ denote the set of prime numbers and let
$s \in \mathbb{R}$ (or $\mathbb{C}$) be the PrimeFlux dimension
parameter. A \emph{PF state} is a function
\[
  \Psi : \mathcal{P} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C},
\]
which assigns to each prime shell $p$ and dimension $s$ a complex
\emph{distinction amplitude}. We write
\[
  \mathcal{H}_{PF} := \{ \Psi : \mathcal{P} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C} \}
\]
for the resulting complex vector space of PF states.

A \emph{distinction field} is a function
\[
  X : \mathcal{P} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C}
\]
which describes an infinitesimal change of the PF distinction
distribution at each prime and dimension. To each distinction field $X$
we associate a linear operator
\[
  D_X : \mathcal{H}_{PF} \to \mathcal{H}_{PF},
\]
which acts on states by
\[
  (D_X \Psi)(p,s)
  = X(p,s)\,\Psi(p,s) + \partial_s X(p,s) \,\Psi(p,s),
\]
or, more generally, by any linear combination of multiplication and
(sufficiently regular) differentiation in $s$. The precise analytic
form is not important for the algebraic structure; what matters is that
$D_X$ is a linear operator depending linearly on $X$.

Define
\[
  \mathfrak{g}_{PF} := \{ D_X \mid X \text{ a distinction field} \}
  \subseteq \mathrm{End}(\mathcal{H}_{PF}),
\]
with the obvious vector space structure
$a D_X + b D_Y := D_{aX + bY}$ for $a,b \in \mathbb{C}$. Informally,
$\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ is the space of \emph{distinction flows} on the
PrimeFlux manifold.

\subsection{Lie bracket from commutators of flows}

We now use the standard commutator of operators as the Lie bracket.

\begin{definition}[PF Lie bracket]
  For $D_X, D_Y \in \mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ we define
  \[
    [D_X, D_Y] := D_X \circ D_Y - D_Y \circ D_X \in \mathrm{End}(\mathcal{H}_{PF}).
  \]
\end{definition}

Because $\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ is a subspace of $\mathrm{End}(\mathcal{H}_{PF})$
closed under commutator, this bracket is well defined and stays inside
$\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$.

\begin{proposition}
  The pair $(\mathfrak{g}_{PF}, [\cdot,\cdot])$ is a complex Lie algebra.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
We verify the three axioms.

\smallskip
\noindent
(1) \emph{Bilinearity.}
For $a,b \in \mathbb{C}$ and $D_X,D_Y,D_Z \in \mathfrak{g}_{PF}$,
\[
  [a D_X + b D_Y, D_Z]
  = (a D_X + b D_Y) D_Z - D_Z (a D_X + b D_Y)
  = a[D_X,D_Z] + b[D_Y,D_Z],
\]
and similarly in the second argument, by distributivity of operator composition.

\smallskip
\noindent
(2) \emph{Antisymmetry.}
For all $D_X, D_Y$,
\[
  [D_X,D_Y]
  = D_X D_Y - D_Y D_X
  = - (D_Y D_X - D_X D_Y)
  = -[D_Y,D_X].
\]

\smallskip
\noindent
(3) \emph{Jacobi identity.}
For any linear operators $A,B,C$ on a vector space it is standard that
\[
  [A,[B,C]] + [B,[C,A]] + [C,[A,B]] = 0.
\]
Taking $A=D_X$, $B=D_Y$, $C=D_Z$ with $D_X,D_Y,D_Z \in \mathfrak{g}_{PF}$
gives the Jacobi identity.
\end{proof}

In other words, the PrimeFlux distinction flows form a genuine Lie
algebra, with the commutator measuring the failure of two flows to commute:
\[
  [D_X,D_Y] = 0
  \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
  \text{the order of applying $X$ and $Y$ does not matter (abelian),}
\]
\[
  [D_X,D_Y] \neq 0
  \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
  \text{the flows interact and generate curvature (non-abelian).}
\]

\subsection{Prime-root generators and Cartan subalgebra}

To connect with the usual root-system picture, we pick distinguished
generators corresponding to individual primes.

For each prime $p \in \mathcal{P}$, choose a basic distinction field
$X_p$ supported on the shell $p$:
\[
  X_p(p',s) = \delta_{p,p'} f_p(s),
\]
for some fixed profile $f_p$ in $s$. The associated operator
$E_p := D_{X_p}$ is the \emph{prime-root generator} for the $p$-shell.
These generators represent pure pushes along the $p$-th prime direction
in the PF manifold. Their commutators
\[
  [E_p, E_q], \qquad p,q \in \mathcal{P},
\]
encode the curvature and interference induced by applying the $p$-mode
and $q$-mode flows in different orders. In particular,
\[
  [E_p,E_q] = 0
  \quad\text{means the $p$ and $q$ directions commute (abelian sector),}
\]
while
\[
  [E_p,E_q] \neq 0
  \quad\text{means the $p$ and $q$ directions generate non-trivial flux.}
\]

Among all flows, the rail-symmetric, radial PF scalings (those which
rescale $|p^{-s}|$ equally on both rails $6k\pm 1$ without changing phase) commute
with one another. The corresponding subspace
\[
  \mathfrak{h}_{PF} \subset \mathfrak{g}_{PF}
\]
is a natural candidate for a Cartan-like subalgebra: a maximal commuting
subalgebra of $\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$. Relative to $\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$, the
prime-root generators $E_p$ decompose into eigenvectors, and their
eigenvalues play the role of roots in the Lie-theoretic sense. Thus,
at the most basic level, Lie theory's structure
\[
  (\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{h},\text{roots, weights})
\]
appears inside PrimeFlux as
\[
  (\mathfrak{g}_{PF},\mathfrak{h}_{PF},\{E_p\},\text{LCM weight lattice}),
\]
with the usual Lie bracket realized concretely by commutators of
distinction flows on the prime manifold.

\subsection{A toy PF Lie subalgebra}

Fix a prime $p_0 \in \mathcal{P}$ and restrict attention to PF states supported on
$p_0$. The dual-rail decomposition yields a two-dimensional space with basis
vectors $e_{+}$ and $e_{-}$ corresponding to the $p_0 \equiv 1 \pmod{6}$ and
$p_0 \equiv -1 \pmod{6}$ rails. On this space consider the matrices
\[
  H =
  \begin{pmatrix}
    1 & 0 \\
    0 & -1
  \end{pmatrix},\qquad
  E =
  \begin{pmatrix}
    0 & 1 \\
    0 & 0
  \end{pmatrix},\qquad
  F =
  \begin{pmatrix}
    0 & 0 \\
    1 & 0
  \end{pmatrix},
\]
which represent rail-symmetric dilation, rail-raising, and rail-lowering flows.
They satisfy the familiar $\mathfrak{sl}_2$ relations
\[
  [H,E] = 2E,\qquad [H,F] = -2F,\qquad [E,F] = H.
\]
Thus even the smallest PF subsystems reproduce classical Lie algebras, showing
how standard structure constants arise from dual-rail distinction flows.

\section{Brief Review of Root Systems and Lie Theory}
\label{sec:Lie-review}

This section recalls standard Lie-theoretic notions to fix notation.

\subsection{Root systems, simple roots, and Weyl groups}

\begin{definition}[Root system]
Let $V$ be a Euclidean space with inner product $(\cdot,\cdot)$. A finite subset
$\Phi\subset V\setminus\{0\}$ is a \emph{root system} if (i) $\Phi$ spans $V$,
(ii) $\alpha\in\Phi\Rightarrow -\alpha\in\Phi$, (iii) the reflection
$s_\alpha(v)=v-2(\alpha,v)/(\alpha,\alpha)\,\alpha$ preserves $\Phi$, and (iv)
$2(\alpha,\beta)/(\alpha,\alpha)\in\mathbb{Z}$ for all $\alpha,\beta\in\Phi$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Simple roots and positive roots]
A subset $\Delta=\{\alpha_1,\dots,\alpha_\ell\}\subset\Phi$ is a set of \emph{simple roots}
if $\Delta$ is a basis of $V$ and each $\beta\in\Phi$ is either a nonnegative or
nonpositive integer combination of the $\alpha_i$. The corresponding positive roots
are those with nonnegative coefficients.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Weyl group]
The \emph{Weyl group} $W$ of $\Phi$ is the group generated by the reflections
$s_\alpha$ for $\alpha\in\Phi$. It acts faithfully on $V$ and permutes the roots.
\end{definition}

\subsection{Weight lattices and minuscule representations}

\begin{definition}[Weight lattice]
For a root system $\Phi$ with coroots $\alpha^\vee=2\alpha/(\alpha,\alpha)$, the
\emph{weight lattice} is
$\Lambda=\{\lambda\in V \mid (\lambda,\alpha^\vee)\in\mathbb{Z}\ \text{for all }\alpha\in\Phi\}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Minuscule weight / representation]
A dominant weight $\lambda$ is \emph{minuscule} if $(\lambda,\alpha^\vee)\in\{0,1\}$ for
every positive coroot. The irreducible representation of highest weight $\lambda$ is
called minuscule; its weights form a single Weyl orbit.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
Minuscule representations furnish the smallest nontrivial orbits of the Weyl group and
play an outsized role in the combinatorics of homogeneous spaces, which motivates the
PF comparison later on.
\end{remark}

\section{A PrimeFlux--Lie Theory Dictionary}
\label{sec:dictionary}

This section develops an explicit correspondence between classical Lie-theoretic
structures and the distinction geometry of PrimeFlux. PF flows, rails, dualities,
and the LCM manifold provide a realization of root systems, weight lattices, Weyl
groups, and representation gradings, incorporating the duality interval $[-1,1]$
and the curvature constants $2, \sqrt{2}, \varphi, \sqrt{\varphi}, \pi, \sqrt{\pi}$.

\subsection{PF distinction curvature and the duality interval}

PrimeFlux features a canonical duality spectrum $[-1,1]$ arising from the two-rail
geometry introduced by the prime $2$. Each value $u\in[-1,1]$ corresponds to a
curvature mode:
\begin{itemize}
  \item $u=-1$: annihilation curvature (anti-resonance, destructive interference).
  \item $u=0$: dimension handoff point (flat curvature boundary).
  \item $u=1$: abelian identity curvature (commuting flows).
  \item $-1<u<1$: dual-rail interference (superposition and reptend mixing).
\end{itemize}
The midpoint $u=\tfrac12$ aligns with the Riemann critical line $\Re(s)=1/2$.
The interval supports the PF involutions $s\mapsto 1-s$, $s\mapsto 1/s$, $s\mapsto -s$,
serving as reflections in the PF root system.

\subsection{Curvature classes and distinguished constants}\label{subsec:curvature-classes}

PF curvature breaks into three classes governed by constants:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Binary curvature: $2$ (minimal distinction split) and $\sqrt{2}$ (dual-rail separation).
  \item Recursive curvature: $\varphi=\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}$ and $\sqrt{\varphi}$ governing harmonic
        dimensions $s=\varphi^n$.
  \item Saturation curvature: $\pi$ and $\sqrt{\pi}$ describing asymptotic curvature in high-dimensional limits.
\end{enumerate}
Ratios such as $\varphi/2$ or $\pi/\sqrt{2}$ measure interactions between the curvature regimes,
analogous to the irrational root-length ratios in Coxeter systems $H_2$, $H_3$, $H_4$.

\subsection{PF roots and Lie roots}

The Cartan-like subalgebra $\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$ consists of rail-symmetric scalings, and prime-root generators
$E_p$ span the non-abelian directions. For $H\in\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$,
\[
  [H,E_p] = \alpha_p(H) E_p,
\]
where $\alpha_p$ is the PF root functional. At $s=\varphi^n$, $\alpha_p(H_\varphi)=\varphi^n-1$, so PF roots
carry $\varphi$-scaled lengths. PF roots correspond to primitive prime-mode flows.

\subsection{PF LCM manifold as a weight lattice}

The PF LCM manifold $\Lambda_{PF}=\bigoplus_{p} \mathbb{Z}\,\omega_p$ encodes PF composite states.
Weights $w=(\nu_p)$ respond to Cartan flows via $H_\varphi\cdot w = (\varphi^{\nu_p}-1)\omega_p$, so $\Lambda_{PF}$
is the PF weight lattice. Binary, recursive, and saturation curvature classes correspond to distinct weight gradings.

\subsection{PF dualities as Weyl reflections}

The maps $s\mapsto 1-s$, $1/s$, $-s$ act on roots and weights, preserving lengths and satisfying $\sigma^2=\mathrm{id}$.
They generate a reflection group $W_{PF}$, analogous to a Weyl group acting on the PF root system.

\subsection{Prime interactions and root strings}

Commutators $[E_p,E_q]$ describe interactions of prime-mode flows and yield PF root strings when they produce other
prime-root directions:
\[
  [E_p,E_q] = \sum_r c_{pqr} E_r.
\]
These capture how prime shells combine, mirroring root strings in Lie theory.

\subsection{$\varphi$-gradings and PF representation theory}

The harmonic dimensions $s=\varphi^n$ define gradings
\[
  V = \bigoplus_{n\in\mathbb{Z}} V_{\varphi^n},
\]
where $V_{\varphi^n}$ consists of states with curvature eigenvalues at $s=\varphi^n$, paralleling weight gradings in highest-weight representations.

\subsection{Summary table}

\[
\begin{array}{c|c}
\text{Lie Theory} & \text{PrimeFlux} \\
\hline
\mathfrak{g} & \mathfrak{g}_{PF} \\
\mathfrak{h} & \mathfrak{h}_{PF} \\
\text{root } \alpha & \text{prime-mode } E_p \\
\text{root system} & \{E_p\}_{p\in\mathcal{P}} \\
\text{weight lattice } \Lambda & \Lambda_{PF} \\
\text{Weyl reflections} & \text{PF dualities }(s\mapsto 1/s, 1-s, -s) \\
\text{root strings} & \text{commutators }[E_p,E_q] \\
\text{representation grading} & \varphi\text{-ladder PF states} \\
\end{array}
\]

The PF distinction manifold thus carries a Lie-theoretic structure with the duality interval and curvature constants
setting the geometry in which roots, weights, and reflections arise naturally.

\section{Harmonic Dimensions, Duality, and Canonical Curvature Constants}
\label{sec:harmonic-duality}

PrimeFlux features two intertwined themes: the golden sequence of harmonic dimensions
and the duality interval $[-1,1]$ spanned by canonical curvature constants. Merging
these perspectives highlights how PF geometry links attenuation scales, rail dualities,
and canonical numerical parameters.

\subsection{$\varphi$ as a harmonic dimension parameter}

In PrimeFlux, the spectral objects $p^{-s}$ encode curvature decay across
prime shells. The dimension parameter $s$ can be viewed as a scale or
effective dimension of the PF distinction manifold. A natural PF
dimension operator is
\[
  d_{PF}(p,s) := \frac{\ln(p^{\,s})}{\ln \pi},
\]
which measures the relative rate of attenuation of the prime-mode $p$
with respect to $\pi$. The PrimeFlux renormalization ladder arises by
selecting $s$ at the discrete values
\[
  s_n = \varphi^n, \qquad n \in \mathbb{Z}.
\]
These $\varphi^n$ values are fixed points of rail-balanced flows in $\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$: if
$H_f : \Psi(p,s) \mapsto f(s)\Psi(p,s)$ satisfies $f(s_n)=s_n$, then $H_f\Psi(p,s_n)=s_n\Psi(p,s_n)$.

\subsection{Prime-root generators at golden scales}

For each prime $p$ we consider the prime-root generator $E_p := D_{X_p}$
built from rail-supported distinction fields $X_p$. The adjoint action of
$\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$ determines root functionals via $[H,E_p]=\alpha_p(H)E_p$.

\begin{remark}
Heuristically, one may model the Cartan generator $H_\varphi$ so that at the harmonic scales
$s=\varphi^n$ its adjoint action on prime-root generators satisfies
\[
  [H_\varphi,E_p] \approx (\varphi^n - 1)\,E_p,
\]
so that root lengths are naturally expressed in $\varphi$-scaled units, paralleling the irrational
length ratios of Coxeter types $H_2$, $H_3$, and $H_4$.
\end{remark}

\subsection{$\varphi$-harmonic weights and the PF representation lattice}

Composite PF states correspond to weight vectors $w=\sum \nu_p\omega_p$ in $\Lambda_{PF}$.
Under $H_\varphi$, these weights transform by $H_\varphi\cdot w=(\varphi^{\nu_p}-1)\omega_p$,
so the PF weight lattice inherits a $\varphi$-graded structure that mirrors highest-weight
representation gradings.

\subsection{Duality, $\zeta(s)$, and golden renormalization}

PrimeFlux features a duality $p^{-s}\leftrightarrow p^{-1/s}$ exchanging large and small scales.
The golden ratio is self-dual under this exchange, positioning $\varphi$ at the boundary between
PF stability ($s>1$) and PF noise ($s<1$). The zeta function
$\zeta(s)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty n^{-s}$ becomes the spectral signature of distinction flow, with the
golden ladder partitioning $s$-space into PF renormalization strata.

\subsection{Connections to higher-dimensional physics}

The sequence $\varphi^n$ yields effective PF dimensions $\{1.618, 2.618, 4.236, 6.854, 11.09,\dots\}$
that align, up to rescaling, with familiar dimensional counts in 4D effective theories, 7D compactifications,
10D/11D string/M-theory, and 26D bosonic strings. Thus the golden ladder provides a geometric bridge
between PF representation theory and high-energy dimensional hierarchies.

\subsection{PF interpretation of curvature constants}

PF distinguishes three curvature regimes governed by constants:
\begin{itemize}
  \item Binary curvature: $2$ and $\sqrt{2}$ capture minimal distinction splits and rail separation.
  \item Recursive curvature: $\varphi$ and $\sqrt{\varphi}$ encode harmonic dimension growth.
  \item Saturation curvature: $\pi$ and $\sqrt{\pi}$ describe asymptotic orbit statistics.
\end{itemize}
Ratios such as $\varphi/2$, $\pi/2$, and $\sqrt{\pi}/\sqrt{2}$ interpolate between regimes and
serve as renormalization parameters.

\subsection{The PF duality interval}

\begin{definition}[PF duality spectrum]
The PF duality spectrum is the interval $[-1,1]$, where $-1$ denotes annihilation curvature,
$0$ denotes a dimension handoff (flat curvature), and $+1$ denotes abelian identity curvature.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
The midpoint $\tfrac12$ corresponds to maximal rail superposition, matching the real part of the
Riemann critical line $\Re(s)=1/2)$.
\end{remark}

\subsection{Binary origin of the duality spectrum}

\section{PrimeFlux: Core Definitions and Operators}
\label{sec:PF-core}

In this section we introduce the basic objects of the PrimeFlux framework:
prime distinctions, the dual congruence rails, a PF Hamiltonian, an
evolution operator, and the combinatorial manifold built from least common
multiples. The emphasis is on formal definitions; physical interpretation
is postponed to later sections.

\subsection{Primes as distinctions and the dual rails}

Let $\mathcal{P}$ denote the set of prime numbers. In PrimeFlux, each
$p \in \mathcal{P}$ is interpreted as an \emph{irreducible distinction},
and composite integers encode structured interactions of these distinctions.

A standard observation is that every prime $p \geq 5$ satisfies
\[
  p \equiv 1 \pmod{6}
  \quad\text{or}\quad
  p \equiv -1 \pmod{6}.
\]
This partitions all but finitely many primes into two congruence classes.
We therefore define the two PF rails
\begin{align*}
  \mathcal{P}_{+} &:= \{\, p \in \mathcal{P} \mid p \equiv 1 \pmod{6} \,\}, \\
  \mathcal{P}_{-} &:= \{\, p \in \mathcal{P} \mid p \equiv -1 \pmod{6} \,\},
\end{align*}
and treat $\{2,3\}$ as a finite exceptional set. The sets
$\mathcal{P}_{+}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{-}$ are referred to as the positive and
negative rails; they form the basic two-sheet structure on which PrimeFlux is built.

\begin{definition}[Prime distinction amplitudes]
Let $s \in \R$ or $\C$ be a scale parameter. A \emph{prime distinction amplitude}
at scale $s$ is a function
\[
  \Psi(\cdot,s) : \mathcal{P} \to \C, \qquad p \mapsto \Psi(p,s),
\]
interpreted as the contribution of the distinction $p$ at scale $s$.
\end{definition}

In many constructions the multiplicative factors $p^{-s}$ provide a canonical
choice of amplitude, possibly with rail-dependent phases. For the algebraic development
we keep $\Psi$ abstract.

\begin{definition}[PrimeFlux Hamiltonian]\label{def:PF-Hamiltonian}
Let $\Phi_{+}$ and $\Phi_{-}$ be linear operators on PF state spaces
$\mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(+)}$ and $\mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(-)}$ representing evolution on
the positive and negative rails, and let $T$ be a linear operator encoding
coupling between the two rails. The \emph{PrimeFlux Hamiltonian} is the block operator
\[
  H_{PF}
  :=
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \Phi_{+} & T \\
    T^{*}    & \Phi_{-}
  \end{pmatrix},
\]
acting on $\mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(+)} \oplus \mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(-)}$. We assume that
$H_{PF}$ is densely defined and symmetric (or self-adjoint) on a suitable domain.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
Throughout this paper $H_{PF}$ is a structural operator that packages the dual-rail
couplings of PrimeFlux. It need not coincide with a physical Hamiltonian, although
physical interpretations can be grafted onto this algebraic form.
\end{remark}

Informally, $\Phi_{+}$ and $\Phi_{-}$ capture intrinsic dynamics along the rails,
while $T$ and $T^{*}$ measure the interaction between them. The off-diagonal structure
is responsible for interference between prime modes on the two rails.

\subsection{Evolution operator and PF dimension}

Given a Hamiltonian, it is natural to consider its associated flow operator.

\begin{definition}[PF evolution operator]\label{def:PF-evolution}
Let $H_{PF}$ be as in Definition~\ref{def:PF-Hamiltonian}. For $\tau \in \R$ such
that the exponential is defined (e.g. via functional calculus when $H_{PF}$ is
self-adjoint), the \emph{PrimeFlux evolution operator} is
\[
  U_{PF}(\tau) := \exp(- \tau H_{PF}).
\]
\end{definition}

The parameter $\tau$ plays the role of an evolution or flow variable, whereas
$s$ appearing in spectral terms $p^{-s}$ is interpreted as a dimension/scale parameter
of the distinction manifold.

\begin{definition}[PF effective dimension]\label{def:PF-dimension}
Fix a reference base $\pi > 1$. For a prime $p \in \mathcal{P}$ and scale $s$ with
$\Re(s)>0$, the \emph{PF effective dimension} is
\[
  d_{PF}(p,s) := \frac{\ln(p^{\,s})}{\ln \pi} = \frac{s \ln p}{\ln \pi}.
\]
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition}[Basic properties of $d_{PF}$]\label{prop:dPF-basic}
Let $p$ be a fixed prime.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
  \item For real $s_1,s_2$, $d_{PF}(p,s_1+s_2)=d_{PF}(p,s_1)+d_{PF}(p,s_2)$.
  \item For $s>0$, $p \mapsto d_{PF}(p,s)$ is strictly increasing.
  \item For $s \neq 0$,
    \[
      d_{PF}(p,1/s) = \frac{1}{s^2} d_{PF}(p,s^2).
    \]
\end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Parts (a) and (b) follow from logarithm identities and monotonicity. For (c),
\[
  d_{PF}(p,1/s) = \frac{1}{s}\frac{\ln p}{\ln \pi}
  = \frac{1}{s^2} \left(s \frac{\ln p}{\ln \pi}\right)
  = \frac{1}{s^2} d_{PF}(p,s^2).
\]
\end{proof}

\subsection{The PF LCM manifold}\label{subsec:PF-LCM}

\begin{definition}[PF LCM manifold]\label{def:PF-LCM}
Let $\mathcal{P}$ denote the set of prime numbers. The \emph{PF LCM manifold} is the
free abelian group
\[
  \Lambda_{\!PF} := \bigoplus_{p\in\mathcal{P}} \mathbb{Z}\,\omega_p,
\]
whose basis vectors $\omega_p$ correspond to prime distinctions. A weight vector
\[
  w = \sum_{p\in\mathcal{P}} \nu_p\,\omega_p
\]
encodes the $p$-adic exponents of a composite state
\[
  n = \prod_{p\in\mathcal{P}} p^{\nu_p}.
\]
For each $s$ with $\Re(s)>0$, the PF LCM manifold is equipped with a curvature metric
$g_s$ defined on basis vectors by
\[
  g_s(\omega_p,\omega_q) = \delta_{pq}\,p^{-s},
\]
extended bilinearly; we refer to $\{g_s\}_s$ as the PF curvature family. Rail-interaction
terms determined by the PF Hamiltonian $H_{PF}$ enrich these metrics, turning
$\Lambda_{\!PF}$ into a weighted distinction manifold induced by prime attenuation and dual-rail dynamics.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}\label{rmk:LCM-interpretation}
\hfill
\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(1) Weight-lattice interpretation.}
The PF LCM manifold plays the same structural role as the weight lattice in classical
Lie theory: primes correspond to fundamental weights $\omega_p$; PF composites are
integral weight vectors; PF flows act linearly on $\Lambda_{\!PF}$.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(2) Superposition and dimensional uplift.}
The exponents $(\nu_p)$ determine the superposition geometry of a PF state:
\[
  n = \prod p^{\nu_p} \quad\longleftrightarrow\quad w = \sum \nu_p \omega_p,
\]
where $w$ is a point in a countably infinite-dimensional Euclidean space with PF
curvature. The attenuation $p^{-s}$ and its dual $p^{-1/s}$ determine the effective PF
dimension, the embedding inside the PF superposition manifold, and how rail phases
encode physical identity.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(3) Roles of $2$ and $3$.}
Primes $2$ and $3$ anchor the two fundamental rail directions $6k\pm1$. They remain
basis elements in $\Lambda_{\!PF}$, but PF geometry distinguishes their scaffolding
role from the curvature primes $p\equiv\pm1\pmod{6}$.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(4) Particle/antiparticle dual manifolds.}
PF duality $p^{-s} \leftrightarrow p^{-1/s}$ induces paired manifolds
$\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(+)}$ and $\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(-)}$ for resonance vs. anti-resonance
states. A PF particle resides on $\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(+)}$ with attenuation $p^{-s}$, and
its dual state lives on $\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(-)}$ with $p^{-1/s}$, forming a Lie-theoretic
pair analogous to $\lambda$ and $-w_0(\lambda)$ in minuscule representation theory.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(5) Physical interpretation.}
The PF LCM manifold encodes the internal address of a composite system and determines
its curvature contribution, resonance phase, PF dual, and representation type under
$\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$. This is the geometric bridge between number-theoretic distinction
fields and Lie-theoretic representation geometry.
\end{remark}

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:PF-metric}
For every $s$ with $\Re(s)>0$, the metric $g_s$ on $\Lambda_{\!PF}$ satisfies:
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
  \item $g_s$ is positive definite.
  \item $g_s$ is bilinear in each argument.
  \item If $0<\Re(s_1)\le \Re(s_2)$ then $g_{s_2}(\omega_p,\omega_p)\le g_{s_1}(\omega_p,\omega_p)$
        for every prime $p$, with equality only when $s_1=s_2$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
By construction $g_s(\omega_p,\omega_q)=\delta_{pq}p^{-s}$ and $p^{-s}$ has positive real part
when $\Re(s)>0$, so (a) and (b) follow from the standard properties of diagonal inner products.
For (c), observe that $p^{-\Re(s_2)}\le p^{-\Re(s_1)}$ whenever $\Re(s_1)\le\Re(s_2)$ with strict
inequality if the real parts differ; the claim extends to all vectors by bilinearity.
\end{proof}

\section{PrimeFlux as a Lie Algebra}
\label{sec:PF-Lie-algebra}

We now identify a natural Lie algebra structure carried by the PrimeFlux
distinction manifold. This structure provides a direct bridge between the
PrimeFlux formalism and the standard language of Lie theory.

\subsection{PF state space and distinction flows}

Let $\mathcal{P}$ denote the set of prime numbers and let
$s \in \mathbb{R}$ (or $\mathbb{C}$) be the PrimeFlux dimension
parameter. A \emph{PF state} is a function
\[
  \Psi : \mathcal{P} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C},
\]
which assigns to each prime shell $p$ and dimension $s$ a complex
\emph{distinction amplitude}. We write
\[
  \mathcal{H}_{PF} := \{ \Psi : \mathcal{P} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C} \}
\]
for the resulting complex vector space of PF states.

A \emph{distinction field} is a function
\[
  X : \mathcal{P} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C}
\]
which describes an infinitesimal change of the PF distinction
distribution at each prime and dimension. To each distinction field $X$
we associate a linear operator
\[
  D_X : \mathcal{H}_{PF} \to \mathcal{H}_{PF},
\]
which acts on states by
\[
  (D_X \Psi)(p,s)
  = X(p,s)\,\Psi(p,s) + \partial_s X(p,s) \,\Psi(p,s),
\]
or, more generally, by any linear combination of multiplication and
(sufficiently regular) differentiation in $s$. The precise analytic
form is not important for the algebraic structure; what matters is that
$D_X$ is a linear operator depending linearly on $X$.

\begin{definition}[Standard distinction field]\label{def:standard-field}
For each prime $p$ we define the \emph{standard distinction field}
\[
  X^{\mathrm{std}}_p(p',s) := \delta_{p,p'}\,p^{-s}.
\]
Its associated operator $D_{X^{\mathrm{std}}_p}$ multiplies the $p$-shell by $p^{-s}$
and serves as the canonical prime-root generator used throughout the paper.
\end{definition}

Define
\[
  \mathfrak{g}_{PF} := \{ D_X \mid X \text{ a distinction field} \}
  \subseteq \mathrm{End}(\mathcal{H}_{PF}),
\]
with the obvious vector space structure
$a D_X + b D_Y := D_{aX + bY}$ for $a,b \in \mathbb{C}$. Informally,
$\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ is the space of \emph{distinction flows} on the
PrimeFlux manifold.

\subsection{Lie bracket from commutators of flows}

We now use the standard commutator of operators as the Lie bracket.

\begin{definition}[PF Lie bracket]
  For $D_X, D_Y \in \mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ we define
  \[
    [D_X, D_Y] := D_X \circ D_Y - D_Y \circ D_X \in \mathrm{End}(\mathcal{H}_{PF}).
  \]
\end{definition}

Because $\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ is a subspace of $\mathrm{End}(\mathcal{H}_{PF})$
closed under commutator, this bracket is well defined and stays inside
$\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$.

\begin{proposition}
  The pair $(\mathfrak{g}_{PF}, [\cdot,\cdot])$ is a complex Lie algebra.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
We verify the three axioms.

\smallskip
\noindent
(1) \emph{Bilinearity.}
For $a,b \in \mathbb{C}$ and $D_X,D_Y,D_Z \in \mathfrak{g}_{PF}$,
\[
  [a D_X + b D_Y, D_Z]
  = (a D_X + b D_Y) D_Z - D_Z (a D_X + b D_Y)
  = a[D_X,D_Z] + b[D_Y,D_Z],
\]
and similarly in the second argument, by distributivity of operator composition.

\smallskip
\noindent
(2) \emph{Antisymmetry.}
For all $D_X, D_Y$,
\[
  [D_X,D_Y]
  = D_X D_Y - D_Y D_X
  = - (D_Y D_X - D_X D_Y)
  = -[D_Y,D_X].
\]

\smallskip
\noindent
(3) \emph{Jacobi identity.}
For any linear operators $A,B,C$ on a vector space it is standard that
\[
  [A,[B,C]] + [B,[C,A]] + [C,[A,B]] = 0.
\]
Taking $A=D_X$, $B=D_Y$, $C=D_Z$ with $D_X,D_Y,D_Z \in \mathfrak{g}_{PF}$
gives the Jacobi identity.
\end{proof}

In other words, the PrimeFlux distinction flows form a genuine Lie
algebra, with the commutator measuring the failure of two flows to commute:
\[
  [D_X,D_Y] = 0
  \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
  \text{the order of applying $X$ and $Y$ does not matter (abelian),}
\]
\[
  [D_X,D_Y] \neq 0
  \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
  \text{the flows interact and generate curvature (non-abelian).}
\]

\subsection{Prime-root generators and Cartan subalgebra}

To connect with the usual root-system picture, we pick distinguished
generators corresponding to individual primes.

For each prime $p \in \mathcal{P}$, choose a basic distinction field
$X_p$ supported on the shell $p$:
\[
  X_p(p',s) = \delta_{p,p'} f_p(s),
\]
for some fixed profile $f_p$ in $s$. The associated operator
$E_p := D_{X_p}$ is the \emph{prime-root generator} for the $p$-shell.
These generators represent pure pushes along the $p$-th prime direction
in the PF manifold. Their commutators
\[
  [E_p, E_q], \qquad p,q \in \mathcal{P},
\]
encode the curvature and interference induced by applying the $p$-mode
and $q$-mode flows in different orders. In particular,
\[
  [E_p,E_q] = 0
  \quad\text{means the $p$ and $q$ directions commute (abelian sector),}
\]
while
\[
  [E_p,E_q] \neq 0
  \quad\text{means the $p$ and $q$ directions generate non-trivial flux.}
\]

Among all flows, the rail-symmetric, radial PF scalings (those which
rescale $|p^{-s}|$ equally on both rails $6k\pm 1$ without changing phase) commute
with one another. The corresponding subspace
\[
  \mathfrak{h}_{PF} \subset \mathfrak{g}_{PF}
\]
is a natural candidate for a Cartan-like subalgebra: a maximal commuting
subalgebra of $\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$. Relative to $\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$, the
prime-root generators $E_p$ decompose into eigenvectors, and their
eigenvalues play the role of roots in the Lie-theoretic sense. Thus,
at the most basic level, Lie theory's structure
\[
  (\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{h},\text{roots, weights})
\]
appears inside PrimeFlux as
\[
  (\mathfrak{g}_{PF},\mathfrak{h}_{PF},\{E_p\},\text{LCM weight lattice}),
\]
with the usual Lie bracket realized concretely by commutators of
distinction flows on the prime manifold.

\subsection{A toy PF Lie subalgebra}

Fix a prime $p_0 \in \mathcal{P}$ and restrict attention to PF states supported on
$p_0$. The dual-rail decomposition yields a two-dimensional space with basis
vectors $e_{+}$ and $e_{-}$ corresponding to the $p_0 \equiv 1 \pmod{6}$ and
$p_0 \equiv -1 \pmod{6}$ rails. On this space consider the matrices
\[
  H =
  \begin{pmatrix}
    1 & 0 \\
    0 & -1
  \end{pmatrix},\qquad
  E =
  \begin{pmatrix}
    0 & 1 \\
    0 & 0
  \end{pmatrix},\qquad
  F =
  \begin{pmatrix}
    0 & 0 \\
    1 & 0
  \end{pmatrix},
\]
which represent rail-symmetric dilation, rail-raising, and rail-lowering flows.
They satisfy the familiar $\mathfrak{sl}_2$ relations
\[
  [H,E] = 2E,\qquad [H,F] = -2F,\qquad [E,F] = H.
\]
Thus even the smallest PF subsystems reproduce classical Lie algebras, showing
how standard structure constants arise from dual-rail distinction flows.

\section{Brief Review of Root Systems and Lie Theory}
\label{sec:Lie-review}

This section recalls standard Lie-theoretic notions to fix notation.

\subsection{Root systems, simple roots, and Weyl groups}

\begin{definition}[Root system]
Let $V$ be a Euclidean space with inner product $(\cdot,\cdot)$. A finite subset
$\Phi\subset V\setminus\{0\}$ is a \emph{root system} if (i) $\Phi$ spans $V$,
(ii) $\alpha\in\Phi\Rightarrow -\alpha\in\Phi$, (iii) the reflection
$s_\alpha(v)=v-2(\alpha,v)/(\alpha,\alpha)\,\alpha$ preserves $\Phi$, and (iv)
$2(\alpha,\beta)/(\alpha,\alpha)\in\mathbb{Z}$ for all $\alpha,\beta\in\Phi$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Simple roots and positive roots]
A subset $\Delta=\{\alpha_1,\dots,\alpha_\ell\}\subset\Phi$ is a set of \emph{simple roots}
if $\Delta$ is a basis of $V$ and each $\beta\in\Phi$ is either a nonnegative or
nonpositive integer combination of the $\alpha_i$. The corresponding positive roots
are those with nonnegative coefficients.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Weyl group]
The \emph{Weyl group} $W$ of $\Phi$ is the group generated by the reflections
$s_\alpha$ for $\alpha\in\Phi$. It acts faithfully on $V$ and permutes the roots.
\end{definition}

\subsection{Weight lattices and minuscule representations}

\begin{definition}[Weight lattice]
For a root system $\Phi$ with coroots $\alpha^\vee=2\alpha/(\alpha,\alpha)$, the
\emph{weight lattice} is
$\Lambda=\{\lambda\in V \mid (\lambda,\alpha^\vee)\in\mathbb{Z}\ \text{for all }\alpha\in\Phi\}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Minuscule weight / representation]
A dominant weight $\lambda$ is \emph{minuscule} if $(\lambda,\alpha^\vee)\in\{0,1\}$ for
every positive coroot. The irreducible representation of highest weight $\lambda$ is
called minuscule; its weights form a single Weyl orbit.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
Minuscule representations furnish the smallest nontrivial orbits of the Weyl group and
play an outsized role in the combinatorics of homogeneous spaces, which motivates the
PF comparison later on.
\end{remark}

\section{A PrimeFlux--Lie Theory Dictionary}
\label{sec:dictionary}

This section develops an explicit correspondence between classical Lie-theoretic
structures and the distinction geometry of PrimeFlux. PF flows, rails, dualities,
and the LCM manifold provide a realization of root systems, weight lattices, Weyl
groups, and representation gradings, incorporating the duality interval $[-1,1]$
and the curvature constants $2, \sqrt{2}, \varphi, \sqrt{\varphi}, \pi, \sqrt{\pi}$.

\subsection{PF distinction curvature and the duality interval}

PrimeFlux features a canonical duality spectrum $[-1,1]$ arising from the two-rail
geometry introduced by the prime $2$. Each value $u\in[-1,1]$ corresponds to a
curvature mode:
\begin{itemize}
  \item $u=-1$: annihilation curvature (anti-resonance, destructive interference).
  \item $u=0$: dimension handoff point (flat curvature boundary).
  \item $u=1$: abelian identity curvature (commuting flows).
  \item $-1<u<1$: dual-rail interference (superposition and reptend mixing).
\end{itemize}
The midpoint $u=\tfrac12$ aligns with the Riemann critical line $\Re(s)=1/2$.
The interval supports the PF involutions $s\mapsto 1-s$, $s\mapsto 1/s$, $s\mapsto -s$,
serving as reflections in the PF root system.

\subsection{Curvature classes and distinguished constants}\label{subsec:curvature-classes}

PF curvature breaks into three classes governed by constants:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Binary curvature: $2$ (minimal distinction split) and $\sqrt{2}$ (dual-rail separation).
  \item Recursive curvature: $\varphi=\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}$ and $\sqrt{\varphi}$ governing harmonic
        dimensions $s=\varphi^n$.
  \item Saturation curvature: $\pi$ and $\sqrt{\pi}$ describing asymptotic curvature in high-dimensional limits.
\end{enumerate}
Ratios such as $\varphi/2$ or $\pi/\sqrt{2}$ measure interactions between the curvature regimes,
analogous to the irrational root-length ratios in Coxeter systems $H_2$, $H_3$, $H_4$.

\subsection{PF roots and Lie roots}

The Cartan-like subalgebra $\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$ consists of rail-symmetric scalings, and prime-root generators
$E_p$ span the non-abelian directions. For $H\in\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$,
\[
  [H,E_p] = \alpha_p(H) E_p,
\]
where $\alpha_p$ is the PF root functional. At $s=\varphi^n$, $\alpha_p(H_\varphi)=\varphi^n-1$, so PF roots
carry $\varphi$-scaled lengths. PF roots correspond to primitive prime-mode flows.

\subsection{PF LCM manifold as a weight lattice}

The PF LCM manifold $\Lambda_{PF}=\bigoplus_{p} \mathbb{Z}\,\omega_p$ encodes PF composite states.
Weights $w=(\nu_p)$ respond to Cartan flows via $H_\varphi\cdot w = (\varphi^{\nu_p}-1)\omega_p$, so $\Lambda_{PF}$
is the PF weight lattice. Binary, recursive, and saturation curvature classes correspond to distinct weight gradings.

\subsection{PF dualities as Weyl reflections}

The maps $s\mapsto 1-s$, $1/s$, $-s$ act on roots and weights, preserving lengths and satisfying $\sigma^2=\mathrm{id}$.
They generate a reflection group $W_{PF}$, analogous to a Weyl group acting on the PF root system.

\subsection{Prime interactions and root strings}

Commutators $[E_p,E_q]$ describe interactions of prime-mode flows and yield PF root strings when they produce other
prime-root directions:
\[
  [E_p,E_q] = \sum_r c_{pqr} E_r.
\]
These capture how prime shells combine, mirroring root strings in Lie theory.

\subsection{$\varphi$-gradings and PF representation theory}

The harmonic dimensions $s=\varphi^n$ define gradings
\[
  V = \bigoplus_{n\in\mathbb{Z}} V_{\varphi^n},
\]
where $V_{\varphi^n}$ consists of states with curvature eigenvalues at $s=\varphi^n$, paralleling weight gradings in highest-weight representations.

\subsection{Summary table}

\[
\begin{array}{c|c}
\text{Lie Theory} & \text{PrimeFlux} \\
\hline
\mathfrak{g} & \mathfrak{g}_{PF} \\
\mathfrak{h} & \mathfrak{h}_{PF} \\
\text{root } \alpha & \text{prime-mode } E_p \\
\text{root system} & \{E_p\}_{p\in\mathcal{P}} \\
\text{weight lattice } \Lambda & \Lambda_{PF} \\
\text{Weyl reflections} & \text{PF dualities }(s\mapsto 1/s, 1-s, -s) \\
\text{root strings} & \text{commutators }[E_p,E_q] \\
\text{representation grading} & \varphi\text{-ladder PF states} \\
\end{array}
\]

The PF distinction manifold thus carries a Lie-theoretic structure with the duality interval and curvature constants
setting the geometry in which roots, weights, and reflections arise naturally.

\section{Harmonic Dimensions, $\varphi$-Scaling, and Duality}
\label{sec:harmonic-duality}

PrimeFlux features two intertwined themes: the golden sequence of harmonic dimensions
and the duality interval $[-1,1]$ spanned by canonical curvature constants. Merging
these perspectives highlights how PF geometry links attenuation scales, rail dualities,
and canonical numerical parameters.

\subsection{$\varphi$ as a harmonic dimension parameter}

In PrimeFlux, the spectral objects $p^{-s}$ encode curvature decay across
prime shells. The dimension parameter $s$ can be viewed as a scale or
effective dimension of the PF distinction manifold. A natural PF
dimension operator is
\[
  d_{PF}(p,s) := \frac{\ln(p^{\,s})}{\ln \pi},
\]
which measures the relative rate of attenuation of the prime-mode $p$
with respect to $\pi$. The PrimeFlux renormalization ladder arises by
selecting $s$ at the discrete values
\[
  s_n = \varphi^n, \qquad n \in \mathbb{Z}.
\]
These $\varphi^n$ values are fixed points of rail-balanced flows in $\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$: if
$H_f : \Psi(p,s) \mapsto f(s)\Psi(p,s)$ satisfies $f(s_n)=s_n$, then $H_f\Psi(p,s_n)=s_n\Psi(p,s_n)$.

\subsection{Prime-root generators at golden scales}

For each prime $p$ we consider the prime-root generator $E_p := D_{X_p}$
built from rail-supported distinction fields $X_p$. The adjoint action of
$\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$ determines root functionals via $[H,E_p]=\alpha_p(H)E_p$.

\begin{remark}
Heuristically, one may model the Cartan generator $H_\varphi$ so that at the harmonic scales
$s=\varphi^n$ its adjoint action on prime-root generators satisfies
\[
  [H_\varphi,E_p] \approx (\varphi^n - 1)\,E_p,
\]
so that root lengths are naturally expressed in $\varphi$-scaled units, paralleling the irrational
length ratios of Coxeter types $H_2$, $H_3$, and $H_4$.
\end{remark}

\subsection{$\varphi$-harmonic weights and the PF representation lattice}

Composite PF states correspond to weight vectors $w=\sum \nu_p\omega_p$ in $\Lambda_{PF}$.
Under $H_\varphi$, these weights transform by $H_\varphi\cdot w=(\varphi^{\nu_p}-1)\omega_p$,
so the PF weight lattice inherits a $\varphi$-graded structure that mirrors highest-weight
representation gradings.

\subsection{Duality, $\zeta(s)$, and golden renormalization}

PrimeFlux features a duality $p^{-s}\leftrightarrow p^{-1/s}$ exchanging large and small scales.
The golden ratio is self-dual under this exchange, positioning $\varphi$ at the boundary between
PF stability ($s>1$) and PF noise ($s<1$). The zeta function
$\zeta(s)=\sum_{n=1}^\infty n^{-s}$ becomes the spectral signature of distinction flow, with the
golden ladder partitioning $s$-space into PF renormalization strata.

\subsection{Connections to higher-dimensional physics}

The sequence $\varphi^n$ yields effective PF dimensions $\{1.618, 2.618, 4.236, 6.854, 11.09,\dots\}$
that align, up to rescaling, with familiar dimensional counts in 4D effective theories, 7D compactifications,
10D/11D string/M-theory, and 26D bosonic strings. Thus the golden ladder provides a geometric bridge
between PF representation theory and high-energy dimensional hierarchies.

\subsection{Summary}

The golden ladder $s=\varphi^n$ furnishes canonical PF gradings, stabilizes prime-root flows,
and bridges PF distinction geometry with familiar high-energy dimensional hierarchies. The next
section isolates the $[-1,1]$ duality interval and its curvature constants, making precise the
binary/recursive/saturation regimes alluded to above.

\section{PF Duality Interval $[-1,1]$ and Curvature Constants}
\label{sec:duality-interval}

\subsection{Curvature classes and canonical constants}

PrimeFlux distinguishes three curvature regimes governed by constants:
\begin{itemize}
  \item Binary curvature: $2$ and $\sqrt{2}$ capture minimal distinction splits and rail separation.
  \item Recursive curvature: $\varphi$ and $\sqrt{\varphi}$ encode harmonic dimension growth.
  \item Saturation curvature: $\pi$ and $\sqrt{\pi}$ describe asymptotic orbit statistics.
\end{itemize}
Ratios such as $\varphi/2$, $\pi/2$, and $\sqrt{\pi}/\sqrt{2}$ interpolate between regimes and
serve as renormalization parameters.

\subsection{PF duality spectrum}

\begin{definition}[PF duality spectrum]
The PF duality spectrum is the interval $[-1,1]$, where $-1$ denotes annihilation curvature,
$0$ denotes a dimension handoff (flat curvature), and $+1$ denotes abelian identity curvature.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
The midpoint $\tfrac12$ corresponds to maximal rail superposition, matching the real part of the
Riemann critical line $\Re(s)=1/2)$.
\end{remark}

\subsection{Origin of the duality interval}

\begin{remark}[Origin of $[-1,1]$]
Reducing $\mathbb{Z}$ modulo $6$ isolates the rails $6k\pm 1$, but the bifurcation itself is driven
by the prime $2$. Normalizing curvature by the binary scale, $C_{\mathrm{norm}}=C/2$, yields values
in $[-1,1]$ and explains why binary curvature anchors the duality spectrum.
\end{remark}

\subsection{Root and weight geometry}

For prime-root generators $E_p$, normalized commutators $[E_p,E_q]$ take values in $[-1,1]$,
delineating abelian versus maximally non-abelian pairs. Similarly, a weight
$w=(\nu_p)$ acquires curvature $C(w)=\sum_p \nu_p \alpha_p$ with $\alpha_p\in[-1,1]$.

\subsection{PF duality group}

\begin{definition}[PF duality group]\label{def:PF-duality-group}
Let $\sigma_{1}(s)=1-s$, $\sigma_{2}(s)=1/s$ (defined for $s\neq 0$), and $\sigma_{3}(s)=-s$.
The \emph{PF duality group} is the subgroup
\[
  W_{PF} := \langle \sigma_{1},\sigma_{2},\sigma_{3} \rangle
\]
of transformations generated by these involutions.
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition}
Each generator of $W_{PF}$ squares to the identity on its domain.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
The identities $(1-(1-s))=s$, $(1/(1/s))=s$ for $s\neq 0$, and $-(-s)=s$ are immediate,
showing $\sigma_i^2=\mathrm{id}$ for $i=1,2,3$.
\end{proof}

\subsection{Curvature operators and flow regimes}

Binary, recursive, and saturation constants $(2,\sqrt{2})$, $(\varphi,\sqrt{\varphi})$, and
$(\pi,\sqrt{\pi})$ organize PF curvature and determine the operators $\{-1,0,1,2,3\}$ that act
on PF flows. Ratios such as $\pi/2$ and $\sqrt{\pi}/\sqrt{2}$ arise as scaling factors between
rail separation and global saturation, while PF dualities $s\mapsto 1/s$, $1-s$, $-s$ act on these
constants to form the reflection group $W_{PF}$.

\subsection{Summary}

The hierarchy
\[
  \text{Binary }(2,\sqrt{2}) \quad\rightarrow\quad \text{Recursive }(\varphi,\sqrt{\varphi})
  \quad\rightarrow\quad \text{Saturation }(\pi,\sqrt{\pi})
\]
captures how the duality interval $[-1,1]$, canonical curvature constants, and PF flow operators
fit together. These scalings provide the curvature counterpart to the harmonic gradings discussed
in Section~\ref{sec:harmonic-duality}.

We refer to \emph{minimal PF states} as distinction configurations generated by a small,

\section{PrimeFlux, Renormalization, and Millennium Problems}
\label{sec:PF-millennium}

This section is heuristic in nature. Its purpose is to illustrate how the PF--Lie framework
may provide a common geometric language for several conjectures, rather than to claim any
formal solution.

We now sketch how the PF--Lie framework offers a common geometric setting for several
Millennium problems, focusing on renormalization and the Yang--Mills mass gap. The
discussion is heuristic: PF provides a coordinate system rather than a solution.

\subsection{Renormalization as motion in PF harmonic dimension}

PF dynamics is organized by the scale $s\in\mathbb{R}$ (or $\mathbb{C}$), interpreted as an
effective dimension. Spectral factors $p^{-s}$ determine curvature on the PF manifold, and
the golden ratio produces harmonic dimensions $s_n=\varphi^n$ where Cartan flows have fixed points.
Renormalization corresponds to varying $s$ (analogous to $\log\mu$). Given a PF Hamiltonian
$H_{PF}(s)$ on a representation $V$, renormalization is the flow $s\mapsto H_{PF}(s)$ and
the induced evolution of effective couplings $g(s)$.

\begin{definition}[PF renormalization trajectory]

  \item \textbf{Tensor products.} Is there a PF tensor product compatible with generalized representation rings?

\begin{abstract}
PrimeFlux is a number-theoretic framework in which primes represent
irreducible informational distinctions and composites represent structured
interactions of these distinctions. The purpose of this paper is twofold:
(1) to formalize the core objects and operators of PrimeFlux in standard
mathematical language, and (2) to relate these objects to the classical
structure of Lie theory, including root systems, weight lattices, Weyl
groups, and minuscule representations. We describe a dictionary between
PrimeFlux constructs and Lie-theoretic data, and we indicate how certain
physical interpretations (particles, fields, curvature) can be expressed
within this combined framework.
\end{abstract}

\section{PrimeFlux: Core Definitions and Operators}
\label{sec:PF-core}

In this section we introduce the basic objects of the PrimeFlux framework:
prime distinctions, the dual congruence rails, a PF Hamiltonian, an
evolution operator, and the combinatorial manifold built from least common
multiples. The emphasis is on formal definitions; physical interpretation
is postponed to later sections.

\subsection{Primes as distinctions and the dual rails}

Let $\mathcal{P}$ denote the set of prime numbers. In PrimeFlux, each
$p \in \mathcal{P}$ is interpreted as an \emph{irreducible distinction},
and composite integers encode structured interactions of these distinctions.

A standard observation is that every prime $p \geq 5$ satisfies
\[
  p \equiv 1 \pmod{6}
  \quad\text{or}\quad
  p \equiv -1 \pmod{6}.
\]
This partitions all but finitely many primes into two congruence classes.
We therefore define the two PF rails
\begin{align*}
  \mathcal{P}_{+} &:= \{\, p \in \mathcal{P} \mid p \equiv 1 \pmod{6} \,\}, \\
  \mathcal{P}_{-} &:= \{\, p \in \mathcal{P} \mid p \equiv -1 \pmod{6} \,\},
\end{align*}
and treat $\{2,3\}$ as a finite exceptional set. The sets
$\mathcal{P}_{+}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{-}$ are referred to as the positive and
negative rails; they form the basic two-sheet structure on which PrimeFlux is built.

\begin{definition}[Prime distinction amplitudes]
Let $s \in \R$ or $\C$ be a scale parameter. A \emph{prime distinction amplitude}
at scale $s$ is a function
\[
  \Psi(\cdot,s) : \mathcal{P} \to \C, \qquad p \mapsto \Psi(p,s),
\]
interpreted as the contribution of the distinction $p$ at scale $s$.
\end{definition}

In many constructions the multiplicative factors $p^{-s}$ provide a canonical
choice of amplitude, possibly with rail-dependent phases. For the algebraic development
we keep $\Psi$ abstract.

\begin{definition}[PrimeFlux Hamiltonian]\label{def:PF-Hamiltonian}
Let $\Phi_{+}$ and $\Phi_{-}$ be linear operators on PF state spaces
$\mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(+)}$ and $\mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(-)}$ representing evolution on
the positive and negative rails, and let $T$ be a linear operator encoding
coupling between the two rails. The \emph{PrimeFlux Hamiltonian} is the block operator
\[
  H_{PF}
  :=
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \Phi_{+} & T \\
    T^{*}    & \Phi_{-}
  \end{pmatrix},
\]
acting on $\mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(+)} \oplus \mathcal{H}_{PF}^{(-)}$. We assume that
$H_{PF}$ is densely defined and symmetric (or self-adjoint) on a suitable domain.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
Throughout this paper $H_{PF}$ is a structural operator that packages the dual-rail
couplings of PrimeFlux. It need not coincide with a physical Hamiltonian, although
physical interpretations can be grafted onto this algebraic form.
\end{remark}

Informally, $\Phi_{+}$ and $\Phi_{-}$ capture intrinsic dynamics along the rails,
while $T$ and $T^{*}$ measure the interaction between them. The off-diagonal structure
is responsible for interference between prime modes on the two rails.

\subsection{Evolution operator and PF dimension}

Given a Hamiltonian, it is natural to consider its associated flow operator.

\begin{definition}[PF evolution operator]\label{def:PF-evolution}
Let $H_{PF}$ be as in Definition~\ref{def:PF-Hamiltonian}. For $\tau \in \R$ such
that the exponential is defined (e.g. via functional calculus when $H_{PF}$ is
self-adjoint), the \emph{PrimeFlux evolution operator} is
\[
  U_{PF}(\tau) := \exp(- \tau H_{PF}).
\]
\end{definition}

The parameter $\tau$ plays the role of an evolution or flow variable, whereas
$s$ appearing in spectral terms $p^{-s}$ is interpreted as a dimension/scale parameter
of the distinction manifold.

\begin{definition}[PF effective dimension]\label{def:PF-dimension}
Fix a reference base $\pi > 1$. For a prime $p \in \mathcal{P}$ and scale $s$ with
$\Re(s)>0$, the \emph{PF effective dimension} is
\[
  d_{PF}(p,s) := \frac{\ln(p^{\,s})}{\ln \pi} = \frac{s \ln p}{\ln \pi}.
\]
\end{definition}

\begin{proposition}[Basic properties of $d_{PF}$]\label{prop:dPF-basic}
Let $p$ be a fixed prime.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
  \item For real $s_1,s_2$, $d_{PF}(p,s_1+s_2)=d_{PF}(p,s_1)+d_{PF}(p,s_2)$.
  \item For $s>0$, $p \mapsto d_{PF}(p,s)$ is strictly increasing.
  \item For $s \neq 0$,
    \[
      d_{PF}(p,1/s) = \frac{1}{s^2} d_{PF}(p,s^2).
    \]
\end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
Parts (a) and (b) follow from logarithm identities and monotonicity. For (c),
\[
  d_{PF}(p,1/s) = \frac{1}{s}\frac{\ln p}{\ln \pi}
  = \frac{1}{s^2} \left(s \frac{\ln p}{\ln \pi}\right)
  = \frac{1}{s^2} d_{PF}(p,s^2).
\]
\end{proof}

\subsection{The PF LCM manifold}\label{subsec:PF-LCM}

\begin{definition}[PF LCM manifold]\label{def:PF-LCM}
Let $\mathcal{P}$ denote the set of prime numbers. The \emph{PF LCM manifold} is the
free abelian group
\[
  \Lambda_{\!PF} := \bigoplus_{p\in\mathcal{P}} \mathbb{Z}\,\omega_p,
\]
whose basis vectors $\omega_p$ correspond to prime distinctions. A weight vector
\[
  w = \sum_{p\in\mathcal{P}} \nu_p\,\omega_p
\]
encodes the $p$-adic exponents of a composite state
\[
  n = \prod_{p\in\mathcal{P}} p^{\nu_p}.
\]
For each $s$ with $\Re(s)>0$, the PF LCM manifold is equipped with a curvature metric
$g_s$ defined on basis vectors by
\[
  g_s(\omega_p,\omega_q) = \delta_{pq}\,p^{-s},
\]
extended bilinearly; we refer to $\{g_s\}_s$ as the PF curvature family. Rail-interaction
terms determined by the PF Hamiltonian $H_{PF}$ enrich these metrics, turning
$\Lambda_{\!PF}$ into a weighted distinction manifold induced by prime attenuation and dual-rail dynamics.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}\label{rmk:LCM-interpretation}
\hfill
\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(1) Weight-lattice interpretation.}
The PF LCM manifold plays the same structural role as the weight lattice in classical
Lie theory: primes correspond to fundamental weights $\omega_p$; PF composites are
integral weight vectors; PF flows act linearly on $\Lambda_{\!PF}$.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(2) Superposition and dimensional uplift.}
The exponents $(\nu_p)$ determine the superposition geometry of a PF state:
\[
  n = \prod p^{\nu_p} \quad\longleftrightarrow\quad w = \sum \nu_p \omega_p,
\]
where $w$ is a point in a countably infinite-dimensional Euclidean space with PF
curvature. The attenuation $p^{-s}$ and its dual $p^{-1/s}$ determine the effective PF
dimension, the embedding inside the PF superposition manifold, and how rail phases
encode physical identity.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(3) Roles of $2$ and $3$.}
Primes $2$ and $3$ anchor the two fundamental rail directions $6k\pm1$. They remain
basis elements in $\Lambda_{\!PF}$, but PF geometry distinguishes their scaffolding
role from the curvature primes $p\equiv\pm1\pmod{6}$.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(4) Particle/antiparticle dual manifolds.}
PF duality $p^{-s} \leftrightarrow p^{-1/s}$ induces paired manifolds
$\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(+)}$ and $\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(-)}$ for resonance vs. anti-resonance
states. A PF particle resides on $\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(+)}$ with attenuation $p^{-s}$, and
its dual state lives on $\Lambda_{\!PF}^{(-)}$ with $p^{-1/s}$, forming a Lie-theoretic
pair analogous to $\lambda$ and $-w_0(\lambda)$ in minuscule representation theory.

\smallskip
\noindent\textbf{(5) Physical interpretation.}
The PF LCM manifold encodes the internal address of a composite system and determines
its curvature contribution, resonance phase, PF dual, and representation type under
$\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$. This is the geometric bridge between number-theoretic distinction
fields and Lie-theoretic representation geometry.
\end{remark}

\begin{lemma}\label{lem:PF-metric}
For every real $s>0$, the metric $g_s$ on $\Lambda_{\!PF}$ satisfies:
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\alph*)]
  \item $g_s$ is positive definite.
  \item $g_s$ is bilinear in each argument.
  \item If $0<s_1 \le s_2$ then $g_{s_2}(\omega_p,\omega_p)\le g_{s_1}(\omega_p,\omega_p)$
        for every prime $p$, with strict inequality whenever $s_1<s_2$.
  \item For any $w=\sum_p \nu_p \omega_p$ with finitely many nonzero $\nu_p$,
        \[
          \lim_{s\to 0^+} g_s(w,w) = \sum_p \nu_p^2,
          \qquad
          \lim_{s\to \infty} g_s(w,w) = 0.
        \]
\end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}
For real $s>0$ we have $g_s(\omega_p,\omega_q)=\delta_{pq}\,p^{-s}$, so
$g_s(\omega_p,\omega_p)=p^{-s}>0$ and $g_s(\omega_p,\omega_q)=0$ when $p\ne q$.
Extending bilinearly to $w=\sum_p \nu_p\omega_p$ yields
\[
  g_s(w,w) = \sum_p \nu_p^2\,p^{-s},
\]
verifying parts (a) and (b). If $0<s_1\le s_2$ then $p^{-s_2}\le p^{-s_1}$,
with strict inequality when $s_1<s_2$, which proves (c). For (d), note that
$p^{-s}\to 1$ as $s\to 0^+$ and $p^{-s}\to 0$ as $s\to\infty$; since the sums
defining $g_s(w,w)$ contain finitely many terms, the limits follow termwise.
\end{proof}

\section{PrimeFlux as a Lie Algebra}
\label{sec:PF-Lie-algebra}

We now identify a natural Lie algebra structure carried by the PrimeFlux
distinction manifold. This structure provides a direct bridge between the
PrimeFlux formalism and the standard language of Lie theory.

\subsection{PF state space and distinction flows}

Let $\mathcal{P}$ denote the set of prime numbers and let
$s \in \mathbb{R}$ (or $\mathbb{C}$) be the PrimeFlux dimension
parameter. A \emph{PF state} is a function
\[
  \Psi : \mathcal{P} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C},
\]
which assigns to each prime shell $p$ and dimension $s$ a complex
\emph{distinction amplitude}. We write
\[
  \mathcal{H}_{PF} := \{ \Psi : \mathcal{P} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C} \}
\]
for the resulting complex vector space of PF states.

A \emph{distinction field} is a function
\[
  X : \mathcal{P} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{C}
\]
which describes an infinitesimal change of the PF distinction
distribution at each prime and dimension. To each distinction field $X$
we associate a linear operator
\[
  D_X : \mathcal{H}_{PF} \to \mathcal{H}_{PF},
\]
which acts on states by
\[
  (D_X \Psi)(p,s)
  = X(p,s)\,\Psi(p,s) + \partial_s X(p,s) \,\Psi(p,s),
\]
or, more generally, by any linear combination of multiplication and
(sufficiently regular) differentiation in $s$. The precise analytic
form is not important for the algebraic structure; what matters is that
$D_X$ is a linear operator depending linearly on $X$.

\begin{definition}[Standard distinction field]\label{def:standard-field}
For each prime $p$ we define the \emph{standard distinction field}
\[
  X^{\mathrm{std}}_p(p',s) := \delta_{p,p'}\,p^{-s}.
\]
Its associated operator $D_{X^{\mathrm{std}}_p}$ multiplies the $p$-shell by $p^{-s}$
and serves as the canonical prime-root generator used throughout the paper.
\end{definition}

Define
\[
  \mathfrak{g}_{PF} := \{ D_X \mid X \text{ a distinction field} \}
  \subseteq \mathrm{End}(\mathcal{H}_{PF}),
\]
with the obvious vector space structure
$a D_X + b D_Y := D_{aX + bY}$ for $a,b \in \mathbb{C}$. Informally,
$\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ is the space of \emph{distinction flows} on the
PrimeFlux manifold.

\subsection{Lie bracket from commutators of flows}

We now use the standard commutator of operators as the Lie bracket.

\begin{definition}[PF Lie bracket]
  For $D_X, D_Y \in \mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ we define
  \[
    [D_X, D_Y] := D_X \circ D_Y - D_Y \circ D_X \in \mathrm{End}(\mathcal{H}_{PF}).
  \]
\end{definition}

Because $\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ is a subspace of $\mathrm{End}(\mathcal{H}_{PF})$
closed under commutator, this bracket is well defined and stays inside
$\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$.

\begin{proposition}
  The pair $(\mathfrak{g}_{PF}, [\cdot,\cdot])$ is a complex Lie algebra.
\end{proposition}

\begin{proof}
We verify the three axioms.

\smallskip
\noindent
(1) \emph{Bilinearity.}
For $a,b \in \mathbb{C}$ and $D_X,D_Y,D_Z \in \mathfrak{g}_{PF}$,
\[
  [a D_X + b D_Y, D_Z]
  = (a D_X + b D_Y) D_Z - D_Z (a D_X + b D_Y)
  = a[D_X,D_Z] + b[D_Y,D_Z],
\]
and similarly in the second argument, by distributivity of operator composition.

\smallskip
\noindent
(2) \emph{Antisymmetry.}
For all $D_X, D_Y$,
\[
  [D_X,D_Y]
  = D_X D_Y - D_Y D_X
  = - (D_Y D_X - D_X D_Y)
  = -[D_Y,D_X].
\]

\smallskip
\noindent
(3) \emph{Jacobi identity.}
For any linear operators $A,B,C$ on a vector space it is standard that
\[
  [A,[B,C]] + [B,[C,A]] + [C,[A,B]] = 0.
\]
Taking $A=D_X$, $B=D_Y$, $C=D_Z$ with $D_X,D_Y,D_Z \in \mathfrak{g}_{PF}$
gives the Jacobi identity.
\end{proof}

In other words, the PrimeFlux distinction flows form a genuine Lie
algebra, with the commutator measuring the failure of two flows to commute:
\[
  [D_X,D_Y] = 0
  \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
  \text{the order of applying $X$ and $Y$ does not matter (abelian),}
\]
\[
  [D_X,D_Y] \neq 0
  \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
  \text{the flows interact and generate curvature (non-abelian).}
\]

\subsection{Prime-root generators and Cartan subalgebra}

To connect with the usual root-system picture, we pick distinguished
generators corresponding to individual primes.

For each prime $p \in \mathcal{P}$ we adopt the standard distinction field
from Definition~\ref{def:standard-field},
\[
  X_p := X^{\mathrm{std}}_p,\qquad
  X_p(p',s) = \delta_{p,p'}\,p^{-s}.
\]
The associated operator $E_p := D_{X_p}$ is the \emph{prime-root generator}
for the $p$-shell. It acts by multiplying the $p$-coordinate of a PF state
by the spectral attenuation factor $p^{-s}$, so that the dependence on the
dimension/scale parameter $s$ is built directly into the flow. These generators represent pure pushes along the $p$-th prime direction
in the PF manifold. Their commutators
\[
  [E_p, E_q], \qquad p,q \in \mathcal{P},
\]
encode the curvature and interference induced by applying the $p$-mode
and $q$-mode flows in different orders. In particular,
\[
  [E_p,E_q] = 0
  \quad\text{means the $p$ and $q$ directions commute (abelian sector),}
\]
while
\[
  [E_p,E_q] \neq 0
  \quad\text{means the $p$ and $q$ directions generate non-trivial flux.}
\]

Among all flows, the rail-symmetric, radial PF scalings (those which
rescale $|p^{-s}|$ equally on both rails $6k\pm 1$ without changing phase) commute
with one another. The corresponding subspace
\[
  \mathfrak{h}_{PF} \subset \mathfrak{g}_{PF}
\]
is a natural candidate for a Cartan-like subalgebra: a maximal commuting
subalgebra of $\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$. Relative to $\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$, the
prime-root generators $E_p$ decompose into eigenvectors, and their
eigenvalues play the role of roots in the Lie-theoretic sense. Thus,
at the most basic level, Lie theory's structure
\[
  (\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{h},\text{roots, weights})
\]
appears inside PrimeFlux as
\[
  (\mathfrak{g}_{PF},\mathfrak{h}_{PF},\{E_p\},\text{LCM weight lattice}),
\]
with the usual Lie bracket realized concretely by commutators of
distinction flows on the prime manifold.

\subsection{A toy PF Lie subalgebra}

Fix a prime $p_0 \in \mathcal{P}$ and restrict attention to PF states supported on
$p_0$. The dual-rail decomposition yields a two-dimensional space with basis
vectors $e_{+}$ and $e_{-}$ corresponding to the $p_0 \equiv 1 \pmod{6}$ and
$p_0 \equiv -1 \pmod{6}$ rails. On this space consider the matrices
\[
  H =
  \begin{pmatrix}
    1 & 0 \\
    0 & -1
  \end{pmatrix},\qquad
  E =
  \begin{pmatrix}
    0 & 1 \\
    0 & 0
  \end{pmatrix},\qquad
  F =
  \begin{pmatrix}
    0 & 0 \\
    1 & 0
  \end{pmatrix},
\]
which represent rail-symmetric dilation, rail-raising, and rail-lowering flows.
They satisfy the familiar $\mathfrak{sl}_2$ relations
\[
  [H,E] = 2E,\qquad [H,F] = -2F,\qquad [E,F] = H.
\]
Thus even the smallest PF subsystems reproduce classical Lie algebras, showing
how standard structure constants arise from dual-rail distinction flows.

\section{Brief Review of Root Systems and Lie Theory}
\label{sec:Lie-review}

This section recalls standard Lie-theoretic notions to fix notation.

\subsection{Root systems, simple roots, and Weyl groups}

\begin{definition}[Root system]
Let $V$ be a Euclidean space with inner product $(\cdot,\cdot)$. A finite subset
$\Phi\subset V\setminus\{0\}$ is a \emph{root system} if (i) $\Phi$ spans $V$,
(ii) $\alpha\in\Phi\Rightarrow -\alpha\in\Phi$, (iii) the reflection
$s_\alpha(v)=v-2(\alpha,v)/(\alpha,\alpha)\,\alpha$ preserves $\Phi$, and (iv)
$2(\alpha,\beta)/(\alpha,\alpha)\in\mathbb{Z}$ for all $\alpha,\beta\in\Phi$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Simple roots and positive roots]
A subset $\Delta=\{\alpha_1,\dots,\alpha_\ell\}\subset\Phi$ is a set of \emph{simple roots}
if $\Delta$ is a basis of $V$ and each $\beta\in\Phi$ is either a nonnegative or
nonpositive integer combination of the $\alpha_i$. The corresponding positive roots
are those with nonnegative coefficients.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Weyl group]
The \emph{Weyl group} $W$ of $\Phi$ is the group generated by the reflections
$s_\alpha$ for $\alpha\in\Phi$. It acts faithfully on $V$ and permutes the roots.
\end{definition}

\subsection{Weight lattices and minuscule representations}

\begin{definition}[Weight lattice]
For a root system $\Phi$ with coroots $\alpha^\vee=2\alpha/(\alpha,\alpha)$, the
\emph{weight lattice} is
$\Lambda=\{\lambda\in V \mid (\lambda,\alpha^\vee)\in\mathbb{Z}\ \text{for all }\alpha\in\Phi\}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{definition}[Minuscule weight / representation]
A dominant weight $\lambda$ is \emph{minuscule} if $(\lambda,\alpha^\vee)\in\{0,1\}$ for
every positive coroot. The irreducible representation of highest weight $\lambda$ is
called minuscule; its weights form a single Weyl orbit.
\end{definition}

\begin{remark}
Minuscule representations furnish the smallest nontrivial orbits of the Weyl group and
play an outsized role in the combinatorics of homogeneous spaces, which motivates the
PF comparison later on.
\end{remark}

\section{A PrimeFlux--Lie Theory Dictionary}
\label{sec:dictionary}

This section develops an explicit correspondence between classical Lie-theoretic
structures and the distinction geometry of PrimeFlux. PF flows, rails, dualities,
and the LCM manifold provide a realization of root systems, weight lattices, Weyl
groups, and representation gradings, incorporating the duality interval $[-1,1]$
and the curvature constants $2, \sqrt{2}, \varphi, \sqrt{\varphi}, \pi, \sqrt{\pi}$.

\subsection{PF distinction curvature and the duality interval}

PrimeFlux features a canonical duality spectrum $[-1,1]$ arising from the two-rail
geometry introduced by the prime $2$. Each value $u\in[-1,1]$ corresponds to a
curvature mode:
\begin{itemize}
  \item $u=-1$: annihilation curvature (anti-resonance, destructive interference).
  \item $u=0$: dimension handoff point (flat curvature boundary).
  \item $u=1$: abelian identity curvature (commuting flows).
  \item $-1<u<1$: dual-rail interference (superposition and reptend mixing).
\end{itemize}
The midpoint $u=\tfrac12$ aligns with the Riemann critical line $\Re(s)=1/2$.
The interval supports the PF involutions $s\mapsto 1-s$, $s\mapsto 1/s$, $s\mapsto -s$,
serving as reflections in the PF root system.

\subsection{Curvature classes and distinguished constants}\label{subsec:curvature-classes}

PF curvature breaks into three classes governed by constants:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item Binary curvature: $2$ (minimal distinction split) and $\sqrt{2}$ (dual-rail separation).
  \item Recursive curvature: $\varphi=\frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2}$ and $\sqrt{\varphi}$ governing harmonic
        dimensions $s=\varphi^n$.
  \item Saturation curvature: $\pi$ and $\sqrt{\pi}$ describing asymptotic curvature in high-dimensional limits.
\end{enumerate}
Ratios such as $\varphi/2$ or $\pi/\sqrt{2}$ measure interactions between the curvature regimes,
analogous to the irrational root-length ratios in Coxeter systems $H_2$, $H_3$, $H_4$.

\subsection{PF roots and Lie roots}

The Cartan-like subalgebra $\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$ consists of rail-symmetric scalings, and prime-root generators
$E_p$ span the non-abelian directions. For $H\in\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$,
\[
  [H,E_p] = \alpha_p(H) E_p,
\]
where $\alpha_p$ is the PF root functional. At $s=\varphi^n$, $\alpha_p(H_\varphi)=\varphi^n-1$, so PF roots
carry $\varphi$-scaled lengths. PF roots correspond to primitive prime-mode flows.

\subsection{PF LCM manifold as a weight lattice}

The PF LCM manifold $\Lambda_{PF}=\bigoplus_{p} \mathbb{Z}\,\omega_p$ encodes PF composite states.
Weights $w=(\nu_p)$ respond to Cartan flows via $H_\varphi\cdot w = (\varphi^{\nu_p}-1)\omega_p$, so $\Lambda_{PF}$
is the PF weight lattice. Binary, recursive, and saturation curvature classes correspond to distinct weight gradings.

\subsection{PF dualities as Weyl reflections}

The maps $s\mapsto 1-s$, $1/s$, $-s$ act on roots and weights, preserving lengths and satisfying $\sigma^2=\mathrm{id}$.
They generate a reflection group $W_{PF}$, analogous to a Weyl group acting on the PF root system.

\subsection{Prime interactions and root strings}

Commutators $[E_p,E_q]$ describe interactions of prime-mode flows and yield PF root strings when they produce other
prime-root directions:
\[
  [E_p,E_q] = \sum_r c_{pqr} E_r.
\]
These capture how prime shells combine, mirroring root strings in Lie theory.

\subsection{$\varphi$-gradings and PF representation theory}

The harmonic dimensions $s=\varphi^n$ define gradings
\[
  V = \bigoplus_{n\in\mathbb{Z}} V_{\varphi^n},
\]
where $V_{\varphi^n}$ consists of states with curvature eigenvalues at $s=\varphi^n$, paralleling weight gradings in highest-weight representations.

\subsection{Summary table}

\[
\begin{array}{c|c}
\text{Lie Theory} & \text{PrimeFlux} \\
\hline
\mathfrak{g} & \mathfrak{g}_{PF} \\
\mathfrak{h} & \mathfrak{h}_{PF} \\
\text{root } \alpha & \text{prime-mode } E_p \\
\text{root system} & \{E_p\}_{p\in\mathcal{P}} \\
\text{weight lattice } \Lambda & \Lambda_{PF} \\
\text{Weyl reflections} & \text{PF dualities }(s\mapsto 1/s, 1-s, -s) \\
\text{root strings} & \text{commutators }[E_p,E_q] \\

\subsection{PF duality group}

\begin{definition}[PF duality group]\label{def:PF-duality-group}
Let $\sigma_{1}(s)=1-s$, $\sigma_{2}(s)=1/s$ (defined for $s\neq 0$), and $\sigma_{3}(s)=-s$.

\[

dimension variable $s$.

The preceding sections establish a mathematical relationship between PrimeFluxâ€”a

\subsection{Rigorous vs conjectural elements}

\begin{itemize}

  \item Identification of $\mathfrak{h}_{PF}$ and prime-root generators $E_p$.

\subsection{Questions for further mathematical investigation}

  \item \textbf{Tensor products.} Is there a PF tensor product compatible with generalized representation rings?
\end{enumerate}

\subsection{Possible extensions}

Future directions include:
\begin{itemize}
  \item Developing a representation theory of $\mathfrak{g}_{PF}$ and classifying irreducible modules.

mathematical language, and (2) to relate these objects to the classical

\section{Introduction}

% Here we will:
